Actually, unless you need/want to have a seperate "channel" for each pickup, i would have added a simple mixing circuit, with a "blend" control. With a single output. So that way you could simply mute the output, and have a blend control to set the balance between the two pickups. The circuit for this would be very simple, and could have the advantage of buffering the impedance* of each pickup. could be built around one double op-amp package. Here is a good example of a mixer, with a tone control circuit..

https://www.aaroncake.net/circuits/mixer2.asp

Here you could have two potentiometers, one for each pickup, to balance out the mix between the two, and a simple tone control. Then just add your mute circuit on the output.


*(Although, i don't know from the vid, what the microphone make/model/ is, and it may already have some pre-amplification/buffering already)

I actually have a bit of experience in this area, having adapted an old eletric piano pedal system (the damper and sustain pedals that you plug into an keyboard) to add a switch that turned the tremolo function on my amplifier on and off. Why would I put this in a piano pedal, you ask? It's because the both pedals, when plugged into an existing multi-function stomp box, were functional - the sustain controlled wah-wah/pitch shift, and the damper allowed you to switch between banks of pre-sets. Once I learned that the piano pedal was ALREADY functional for controlling this other pedal, I was happy to add a third functionality. It's surprisingly easy to make an on/off switch for electronic music gear. If you want to control other things, it gets more complex, but on and off is as simple as circuitry gets.

The most satisfying part of working with shrink tubing is not the part where you actually shrink it. Although that is pretty fun. But no, the most satisfying part of working with shrink tubing comes just before that moment. It's the moment after you've soldered something, and you look at your work, and you see that you did remember to put the shrink tubing on before soldering. Whew! What a relief! Never gets old.

Nice job with this! Next time you solder an XLR connector though: I recommend tinning the solder cups of the connector before putting the wire in them. If you tin your wire and connector beforehand, you can complete the joint by just heating the connector with the iron very quickly, as opposed to holding heat to it while adding solder (which can be tricky if you’re trying to hold a wire to a connector)

One small problem...

If your microphone is a phantom powered condenser mic, or if your mic cord is plugged into an input channel with phantom power (48 volts) turned on, you can short out the channel's power. The better idea would be to interrupt the signal by opening up the circuit rather than shorting it.

Also depending on the design, the input channel's initial amp circuit can be damaged by a short. It would be rare, but possible on some boards. Most of today's boards have resistors inline to inputs of one or more opamps so a short wouldn't be fatal. Still, you have to be careful building a shorting device that will get plugged into an unknown input.

Also, what if the cable doesn't get plugged into a board directly, but into some other device like a balun for the pickup or some outboard gear. Pickups are typically high impedance and need to be plugged into a balun on the stage to change the impedance. These are usually a transformer which can be shorted but some are active devices. You could find that one day the device shorts out something expensive.

If you don't use the pickup and the mic at the same time, you can use the same switch pole for the hot side of the mic and the pickup. This allows you to interrupt both legs of the mic OR the one leg of the pickup plus the light.

you could build the switch into the fiddle as well as pickup & microphone. Which would make for a more compact convenient setup.

As for the tone/timbre of your amplified instrument. It actually shouldn't sound like the fiddle does to the ear.
The natural sound of every instrument on stage is always heavily altered so that everything fits into a mix without frequency overlaps that make things sound unclear, muddy and can set off resonant droning with the acoustics of the room which is fatiguing to listeners.

Guitars have all their bottom end cut, so much so that guitarists may aswell be playing through a battery powered practice amp. (experienced performing guitarists actually use treble boost pedals to increase this effect even further).

Bass guitars have all their top end cut, so they lose pretty much all their tone and sound more like a deep sine wave.

Vocals have bottom cut, are heavily compressed and usually have delay added.

So for fiddle, the best option would probably be to have a separate instrument for stage. One you can install electronics into without care, possibly even active electronics. And engineer it to sound as good as possible in the final mix through PA. This will tonally be radically different to what a great fiddle sounds like in real life.

As an electrical engineer I see where he is coming from but I find it a bit unideal solution. Generally when you switch something off in electronics you want to break the circuit. As when there is no loop (signal and ground both connected), there is no current (ie. muted). By connecting the signal to ground (called shorting) you allow maximum current to pass your circuit, luckily a microphone has very low current output so you don't see much of an effect. Try it with something else and stuff can start breaking fast! Eg. If you connect the possitive and negative terminal of that 9V battery with a wire it will initially give a big spark, and everything will heat up like crazy and your battery will be empty in no time (just search up 'shorting a 9v battery' for yourself)! For future reference: don't use this switching method! Instead break the loop.

The way you muted these things isn't necesserly wrong, but not the best way you could have done it. About the pickup, the entire thing has very little power output so shortcurting won't do much harm. The microphone is a different story. Be it a battery powered one (especially if it has symmetrical output) chances are it has pre-amplifier right after the actual microphone output. The output you shortcut is a pre-amplifier, which leads to overloading it, potentially damagimg the microphone as a whole. Now maybe I'm wrong about pre-amplifier being in your microphone, but there for sure are pre-amplifiers in different ones, so even with the pickup, it's best to break the circuit instead of shorting it. Please note, that if you do so, chances are your output device will become noisy, because the broken input circuit now started picking up electrical noise from your surrounding, with good example being radio transmitters that you probably use to fiddle without being restricted by cables. In order to stop this noise, you must connect the input to the ground. Some may argue that you have still shorted the circuit, but keep in mind that the output from microphone pre-amp isn't being connected to anything, so there's no way it could overload. The part about LED was good tho. It's worth mentioning right resistance for an LED could be roughly around 1k ohms (but even 330 ohms is fine).

If you don't want the audio signal to <POP> on the phantom powered mic level signal, you will need a bank of largish capacitors in parallel to that you short the balanced pair through. This won't entirely cut the signal, but if you find the right capacitors, you will drop the signal gain by like 60-80dB which will effectively mute such a low voltage signal. The capacitors will store the charge of the 48VDC phantom power so that its not a spike when the switch is engaged, thus eliminating the loud audible pop. You could, also build it to power the LED off of the phantom power as well. We do all of this at my job for the custom mute pedal boxes that we build for Broadway pit musicians.

I'd have looked into doing a filter using sensor fusion on the microphone and the pickup together as inputs. That way, you should be able to get the microphone's sound quality but not get your voice or anything.

Not sure if that can be done, though. The sounds you want are in the range of a couple hundred Hz to several kHz. That means your sampling rate must also be low. That limits how fast the filter can respond. And you want a fast response.

Pickup tin can sound is usually because of mismatch impedance, Piezo electric pickups are high impedance, you need a preamp or buffer with a high impedance input, there is an easy high input preamp design called Tillman preamp, try that. I put one in my electric guitar and that solve the problem of losing the highs when reducing the volume, it work great with electric and piezo electric pickpus, it was designed by tillman for double basses and works wonders with violin and other instruments, and the cost of parts is like 10 dlls.

1. For a newb, your solder joints look great.

2. You could use phantom power from the soundsystem to power your LED. You would need a bigger resistor (you have a 4k7, as this scales linearly with the voltage and standard phantom power is 48V, a 22k or 27k would probably do) but it would make the battery obsolete. As your mic is a condenser mic, you need to have phantom power on anyway. You can just attach the led anode to one of the signal cables of the microphone and it should in theory work. If you really wanna be safe you can wire another switch and also add a battery clip, so you can switch between battery powered and phantom powered.
